title: Glevum Way Walking Route

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Glevum Way, near Churchdown
images.caption: Glevum Way, near Churchdown. The Glevum Way was devised by the Gloucester Ramblers Group as part of the Ramblers Association Diamond Jubilee celebrations dating it to 1995. The footpath itself is rather older and is shown on my 1980s vintage Landranger map. The fence at the right is to stop people sneaking into the Gloucestershire Airfield.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / The Glevum Way, near Churchdown
images.caption: The Way is classified as a footpath. The building in the background is the office of a cattery and boarding kennel undertaking.

images.title: Philip Halling / Canal side house, Hardwicke
images.caption: Canal side house, Hardwicke. This canal side house on the Gloucester and Sharpness Canal used to be the site of a bridge, there is a Bridge keeper's cottage on the opposite bank.

images.title: Hardwicke Church across the canal-side fields by Sarah Charlesworth, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hardwicke Church across the canal-side fields

images.title: St Leonard's Church, Upton St Leonards, nr Gloucester by Robert Rimell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: St Leonard's Church, Upton St Leonards, nr Gloucester

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Folland Avenue, Hucclecote, Gloucester
images.caption: Folland Avenue, Hucclecote, Gloucester. The traffic lights manage access onto the old Roman road, Ermin Way, now a minor road since the A417 was diverted around the north of Hucclecote some decades ago.

images.title: Bob Embleton / The River Severn at the White Horse. Walham
images.caption: The River Severn at the White Horse. Walham. Looking downstream towards Gloucester, Bristol and the sea from the grounds of the once riverside pub, but now a Chinese restaurant.

description: This circular walk takes you through the suburbs, countryside and villages around the city of Gloucester. The walk starts at Gloucester's Victorian docks next to the Gloucester Waterways Museum which tells the story of England's canals and rivers. The walk then includes two consecutive waterside sections along the River Severn and the towpath of the Gloucester and Sharpness Canal, taking you to the village of Hardwicke. From Hardwicke the path takes you through some delightful Gloucestershire countryside and the villages of Upton St Leonards, Hucclecote and Churchdown. The walk finishes by passing Gloucestershire Airport and the village of Walham, before returning to the Gloucester docks.
